description: A nostalgic and easy recipe for sugar cookies that melt in your mouth and are perfect for decorating.
ingredients: [{"name": "butter", "units": "cup", "amount": 1}, {"name": "sifted confectioners' sugar", "units": "cups", "amount": 1.5}, {"name": "large egg", "units": "unit", "amount": 1}, {"name": "vanilla extract", "units": "teaspoon", "amount": 1}, {"name": "almond extract", "units": "teaspoon", "amount": 0.5}, {"name": "all-purpose flour", "units": "cups", "amount": 2.5}, {"name": "baking soda", "units": "teaspoon", "amount": 1}, {"name": "cream of tartar", "units": "teaspoon", "amount": 1}, {"name": "granulated sugar", "units": "cup", "amount": 0.25}]
instructions: Cream the softened butter and sifted confectioners' sugar in a large bowl until wonderfully smooth and fluffy. Beat in the large egg, then stir in the vanilla extract and almond extract. In a separate bowl, whisk together the all-purpose flour, baking soda, and cream of tartar. Gradually blend this dry mixture into the creamed ingredients until a soft dough forms. Do not overmix. Cover the dough tightly and refrigerate for at least two hours. Preheat your oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). On a lightly floured surface, roll out each portion of chilled dough to about 3/16 inch thick. Cut out shapes using cookie cutters. Carefully place the cut-out cookies about 1 1/2 inches apart onto greased cookie sheets. Sprinkle the tops of the cookies with granulated sugar. Bake for about 8 minutes, or until the edges are just lightly browned. They should be tender, not crisp. Let the cookies cool on the baking sheet for about 5 minutes before transferring them to a wire rack to cool completely.
notes: Chilling the dough is crucial for the cookies to hold their shape. You can also make the dough a day in advance and chill it.
